page_title: Endoscopic Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful endoscopy depends on cameras that see tissue clearly, flexible shafts that navigate anatomy without breaking, and components that survive repeated cleaning cycles. We test optical resolution per ISO 8600 standards, measure mechanical durability through thousands of bending cycles, and validate that your scope maintains performance after the cleaning protocols hospitals actually use.
primary_content_description:
Endoscopic cameras must resolve enough detail for accurate diagnosis while maintaining color accuracy under varying light conditions. The flexible insertion tube must bend through tight turns without kinking, transmit physician hand movements precisely to the tip, and return to its original shape after each procedure. Meanwhile, working channels must stay patent for instrument passage, and the entire system must withstand hundreds of cleaning and sterilization cycles without degrading optical or mechanical performance.

We measure image resolution across your camera's full field of view using ISO 8600 test patterns. Mechanical testing quantifies minimum bending radius, torque transmission from handle to tip, and structural integrity after 10,000+ flexion cycles. We validate that seals maintain integrity during high-pressure cleaning, that optical components resist fogging and contamination, and that electrical insulation remains intact throughout your scope's claimed lifetime. Testing follows protocols specific to GI, bronchial, urological, and laparoscopic applications.

Your regulatory pathway depends on demonstrating that optical performance meets diagnostic requirements, mechanical components survive clinical use patterns, and biocompatibility testing addresses mucosal contact duration per ISO 10993. We provide the data packages needed for 510(k) submissions, with protocols designed around FDA guidance for flexible endoscopes and the specific contact scenarios your device encounters during procedures.
capability_1_description: We measure how many line pairs per millimeter your camera resolves at center and periphery, quantifying whether image quality supports diagnostic decisions across the full viewing area per ISO 8600 standards.
capability_2_description: We determine the tightest radius your scope navigates without kinking or breaking, measuring insertion force, torque response, and whether the shaft maintains flexibility after repeated bending to maximum specifications.
capability_3_description: We verify that working channels pass instruments of specified diameters, maintain suction capacity, and resist blockage from tissue or fluid debris during simulated procedures.
capability_4_description: We measure whether your scope's design allows complete removal of organic matter from channels and components, using the automated reprocessing systems hospitals actually employ.
capability_5_description: We quantify light distribution across your scope's field of view, measuring whether illumination intensity varies enough to create diagnostic blind spots or misleading shadows.
capability_6_description: We conduct ISO 10993 cytotoxicity, sensitization, and irritation testing based on mucosal contact duration, providing the safety data required for tissue-contacting components.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Endoscopic Device Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our facility includes specialized equipment for testing devices that must navigate complex anatomy. We measure bending performance using radius fixtures from 5mm to 50mm, quantify torque transmission through articulated shafts, and evaluate tip control precision. This infrastructure applies directly to endoscopic insertion tubes, which face the same mechanical challenges as the cardiovascular catheters we've tested for 40 years.
why_choose_2_description: We maintain ISO 8600-compliant optical test benches with resolution targets, color charts, and illumination measurement systems. Our equipment quantifies resolution, contrast sensitivity, and color reproduction under controlled conditions. We can identify whether optical degradation stems from lens quality, fiber bundle damage, or sensor limitations, then correlate findings with your manufacturing specifications.
why_choose_3_description: All testing occurs under GLP protocols per 21 CFR Part 58, with study directors who understand FDA expectations for endoscopic device submissions. Our final reports include the statistical analyses, photographic documentation, and traceability matrices that regulators expect. We've supported dozens of successful 510(k) clearances with this approach.
cta_description: Whether you're developing flexible GI scopes, rigid laparoscopes, or specialty visualization systems, we'll design testing protocols that address your specific regulatory pathway and performance claims.

page_title: Laparoscopic Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful laparoscopic surgery requires instruments where electrical insulation never fails during tissue cutting, trocar seals maintain pneumoperitoneum throughout procedures, and articulation joints deliver precise movements after thousands of cycles. We test whether your electrosurgical insulation withstands the mechanical stress of tissue manipulation, measure how much force surgeons need to actuate your instrument, and validate that seals prevent gas leakage under the pressure conditions surgeons actually encounter.
primary_content_description:
Laparoscopic instruments combine mechanical precision with electrical safety in an environment where insulation failure can cause serious patient injury. Electrosurgical devices must deliver cutting or coagulation energy while maintaining complete insulation integrity along shaft lengths of 30-45cm. Articulating instruments must transmit hand movements through multiple joints without backlash or position drift. Trocars must seal around instruments of varying diameters while maintaining 12-15 mmHg insufflation pressure. All components must survive repeated sterilization cycles without performance degradation.

We measure insulation resistance per IEC 60601 standards, applying mechanical stress while monitoring for current leakage that could cause patient burns. Mechanical testing quantifies actuation forces at the handle, jaw closure forces at the tip, and whether articulation accuracy degrades after 5,000+ cycles. We validate trocar seal performance across instrument diameter ranges, measure CO2 leak rates during simulated instrument exchanges, and verify that valve mechanisms maintain function after repeated autoclaving. Testing addresses general surgery, gynecological, and urological applications.

Your device typically follows a 510(k) pathway demonstrating substantial equivalence to predicate instruments. We provide testing that addresses FDA guidance on electrosurgical safety, mechanical performance verification, and biocompatibility assessment for peritoneal tissue contact per ISO 10993. Our protocols generate the comparative data and safety documentation regulators expect for laparoscopic instrument clearances.
capability_1_description: We measure whether electrical insulation maintains integrity when your instrument bends to maximum radius during tissue manipulation, detecting failure points before they cause patient injury in clinical use per IEC 60601 requirements.
capability_2_description: We quantify CO2 leak rates when instruments of different diameters pass through your trocar seal, measuring whether pneumoperitoneum is maintained during the rapid instrument exchanges that occur in actual surgical procedures.
capability_3_description: We cycle articulating joints through 10,000+ movements while measuring position accuracy, determining whether backlash develops that would compromise surgical precision during complex dissection maneuvers.
capability_4_description: We quantify how much force your jaws apply to tissue when surgeons close the handles completely, verifying adequate grip strength without tissue damage that could cause inadvertent bleeding or perforation.
capability_5_description: We measure how much hand strength surgeons need to actuate your instrument over extended procedures, identifying whether actuation forces cause fatigue that could compromise surgical performance during lengthy operations.
capability_6_description: We validate that repeated exposure to steam sterilization, high-level disinfection, or other reprocessing methods does not degrade mechanical performance, electrical safety, or material properties throughout your instrument's claimed lifetime.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Laparoscopic Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our laboratory includes IEC 60601-compliant test systems that measure leakage current while instruments undergo mechanical stress. We can detect insulation failures at current levels far below what causes patient injury, identifying design weaknesses before clinical use. This equipment supports the electrical safety documentation FDA expects for electrosurgical instruments across all specialized surgical applications.
why_choose_2_description: We've tested precision surgical instruments for 40 years, developing expertise in the mechanical performance and durability requirements that determine clinical success. Our team understands how surgeons actually use laparoscopic tools, which failure modes matter most, and how to design test protocols that predict real-world performance. This experience translates directly to identifying problems early in development.
why_choose_3_description: All testing follows GLP protocols per 21 CFR Part 58, with documentation systems designed around FDA submission requirements. Our study directors understand what regulators look for in laparoscopic instrument testing data. We've supported successful 510(k) clearances for electrosurgical devices, mechanical instruments, and combination products with this approach.
cta_description: Whether you're developing electrosurgical instruments, mechanical graspers, or advanced articulating devices, we'll design protocols that address the specific safety and performance requirements your regulatory pathway demands.
